articles.title: Press release - Air passengers should keep their rights, say MEPs
articles.summary: Transport MEPs reviewing air passenger rights refuse to roll back on compensation for a three-hour delay and push for free cabin luggage and more rights for vulnerable travellers.Committee on Transport and Tourism Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
On Monday, Parliament’s Transport and Tourism Committee voted to update EU air passenger rights rules, in force since 2004, to ensure that passengers are sufficiently protected against travel disruption such as denied boarding and delayed or cancelled flights. This vote represents the draft Parliament response to Council's June 2025 position on air passenger rights.

Standing behind current rights

Transport Committee MEPs reject EU ministers’ push to weaken air passenger rights. They want to maintain air travellers’ right to be reimbursed or re-routed and to claim compensation if a flight is delayed by more than three hours, if it is cancelled, or if they are denied boarding (Council’s position is that compensation should apply only after a four to six hour delay, depending on the flight distance).

The MEPs are also against decreasing the current compensation amounts for flight disruptions and suggest they should be set at between €300 and €600 depending on the flight distance (Council wants to set compensation at between €300 to €500).

The committee acknowledges that airlines’ responsibility for disrupted flights should be limited to situations within their control. The draft position therefore updates the list of the extraordinary circumstances that would waive their responsibility to pay compensation, for instance natural disasters, war, weather conditions or unforeseen labour disputes affecting the air operator, airport or air navigation service provider. MEPs want this list to be exhaustive and ask the Commission to keep it up to date.

The duty to provide stranded passengers with refreshments every two hours of waiting time beyond the initial departure time, a meal after three hours, and an overnight stay of a maximum of three nights for long delays, should remain in all circumstances, they add. This three-night limit would offer airlines greater predictability and spare them undue financial costs, while replacing a situation where no clear cap exists and carriers can be exposed to unlimited accommodation costs in extraordinary circumstances.

Strengthening traveller protection

The MEPs are adamant that passengers must be given clear and timely information on baggage procedures. They advocate for the right to carry on board, at no additional cost, one personal item, such as a handbag, backpack or laptop, plus one small piece of hand luggage with maximum dimensions of 100 cm (combined length, width and height) and weighing no more than 7 kg.

Transport MEPs also want to scrap the additional fees some travellers are forced to pay, for instance for correcting passenger name spelling errors or for checking in. Passengers should retain the right to choose between digital and paper boarding passes, they add.

Vulnerable passengers

The Transport and Tourism Committee pays special attention to passengers with disabilities or reduced mobility, and to children, highlighting the EU’s commitment to inclusivity, accessibility, and social responsibility, and the need to make sure that all passengers travel with dignity.

Under the draft rules, these travellers should have the right to compensation, rerouting and assistance by airlines if they miss a flight due to airport’s failure to help them reach the gate on time. Passengers with reduced mobility, pregnant women, infants, and children in a pram with accompanying person should be given priority when boarding, while accompanying persons should be seated on an adjacent seat without having to pay extra, stress MEPs.

Faster and simpler reimbursement

MEPs want pre-filled forms for compensation and reimbursement requests, to simplify claims processing and help passengers and airlines avoid claim agencies. According to the draft rules, air carriers would need to send passengers facing travel disruption (cancellation or delays) a pre-filled form within 48 hours of a disruption (Council’s position requires a pre-filled form only after cancellation, not after long delays). Travellers would have one year to file a request for compensation.

Quote

Rapporteur Andrey Novakov (EPP, BG) said: ''Again, Parliament is sending a clear message: we will not step back from existing passengers’ rights. The rules people rely on today remain the baseline: we are determined to improve them, not dilute them. The three-hour threshold for compensation, the existing compensation levels, and real, enforceable safeguards for passengers remain our red lines. From pre-filled claim forms when flights are delayed or cancelled to the right to sit next to your child at no extra cost - these are practical rights that must work in real life. We are ready to continue the fight for clearer, more predictable rules for airlines and a stronger aviation sector, but never at the expense of passengers.''

Next step

Parliament’s draft position on air passenger rights was confirmed by 36 votes in favour and with two abstentions. It will go to the January plenary session for a final vote by the House as a whole.

Background information

In 2014, Parliament reacted to a Commission proposal to update air passenger rights, proposing that delayed or stranded air passengers should receive better access to compensation, with clearer rules about how airlines should deal with passenger complaints. Differing positions between EU countries led to progress on this file stalling for 11 years. In June 2025, however, EU ministers reached a political agreement, opening the way for negotiations with Parliament. The interinstitutional talks started in October 2025, but the negotiations did not result in an agreement, forcing Parliament to proceed with the adoption of its second reading position.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the European Parliament's Transport Committee voting to strengthen and maintain air passenger rights, including compensation for delays, protections for vulnerable travelers, and improved reimbursement processes. These changes have broad societal impact by enhancing consumer protections and inclusivity for millions of air travelers across the EU, representing a meaningful policy advancement with clear benefits.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament votes to protect and improve air passenger rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Since 2004, European Union (EU) rules have protected air passengers when flights are delayed, cancelled, or when boarding is denied. Recently, EU ministers proposed changes that would reduce these protections, but the European Parliament's Transport and Tourism Committee disagreed.

**What happened** – On Monday, the committee voted to keep and strengthen passenger rights. They want to keep compensation for delays of three hours or more and maintain current compensation amounts, which range from €300 to €600 depending on flight distance. They also want to make sure airlines only avoid paying compensation in rare, serious cases like natural disasters or strikes. The committee voted to guarantee free cabin luggage, better information about baggage, and to stop extra fees for small mistakes like name spelling or boarding passes. Special attention was given to vulnerable travelers, such as people with disabilities, pregnant women, children, and infants, ensuring they get priority boarding and assistance without extra cost. The committee also wants to speed up reimbursements by requiring airlines to send pre-filled claim forms within 48 hours after delays or cancellations.

**Impact** – This decision protects millions of air passengers across the EU by ensuring clear rights and fair compensation. It also makes traveling easier and fairer for vulnerable groups who often face extra challenges. By stopping some extra fees and improving claim processes, passengers can get help faster and avoid confusion. The rules also give airlines clear limits on costs, which helps balance fairness with business needs.

**What's next step** – The committee’s decision will be voted on by the full European Parliament in January. If approved, it will start negotiations with EU member countries to finalize the updated rules. This process could lead to stronger, clearer passenger protections across Europe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Parliament is strengthening air passenger rights to ensure fair compensation, better services, and special care for vulnerable travelers.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen vote pour protéger et améliorer les droits des passagers aériens
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis 2004, les règles de l’Union européenne (UE) protègent les passagers aériens en cas de retard, d’annulation ou de refus d’embarquement. Récemment, les ministres de l’UE ont proposé de réduire ces protections, mais la commission des Transports et du Tourisme du Parlement européen n’est pas d’accord.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, la commission a voté pour maintenir et renforcer les droits des passagers. Elle souhaite conserver la compensation pour les retards de trois heures ou plus, avec des montants allant de 300 € à 600 € selon la distance du vol. Elle veut aussi que les compagnies aériennes ne soient exonérées de compensation que dans des cas rares et graves comme les catastrophes naturelles ou les grèves. La commission a voté pour garantir un bagage cabine gratuit, une meilleure information sur les bagages, et pour supprimer certains frais supplémentaires, par exemple pour corriger une faute d’orthographe ou pour le choix du billet d’embarquement. Une attention particulière est donnée aux passagers vulnérables, comme les personnes handicapées, les femmes enceintes, les enfants et les nourrissons, qui auront la priorité à l’embarquement et une assistance sans coût supplémentaire. La commission veut aussi accélérer les remboursements en demandant aux compagnies d’envoyer un formulaire pré-rempli dans les 48 heures suivant un retard ou une annulation.

**Impact** – Cette décision protège des millions de passagers dans l’UE en garantissant des droits clairs et une compensation juste. Elle facilite aussi le voyage pour les groupes vulnérables qui rencontrent souvent plus de difficultés. En supprimant certains frais et en améliorant les procédures de réclamation, les passagers peuvent recevoir de l’aide plus rapidement et éviter la confusion. Ces règles fixent aussi des limites claires pour les coûts des compagnies, ce qui équilibre équité et besoins commerciaux.

**Prochaine étape** – La décision de la commission sera soumise au vote du Parlement européen en janvier. Si elle est approuvée, elle lancera des négociations avec les États membres pour finaliser les règles mises à jour. Ce processus pourrait conduire à des protections plus fortes et plus claires pour les passagers dans toute l’Europe.

**En une phrase** – Le Parlement européen renforce les droits des passagers aériens pour garantir une compensation équitable, de meilleurs services et une attention particulière aux voyageurs vulnérables.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento Europeo vota para proteger y mejorar los derechos de los pasajeros aéreos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Desde 2004, las reglas de la Unión Europea (UE) protegen a los pasajeros aéreos cuando los vuelos se retrasan, cancelan o deniegan el embarque. Recientemente, los ministros de la UE propusieron reducir estas protecciones, pero el Comité de Transporte y Turismo del Parlamento Europeo no estuvo de acuerdo.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, el comité votó para mantener y fortalecer los derechos de los pasajeros. Quieren conservar la compensación para retrasos de tres horas o más y mantener las cantidades actuales, que van de 300 € a 600 € según la distancia del vuelo. También quieren que las aerolíneas solo eviten pagar compensación en casos raros y graves como desastres naturales o huelgas. El comité votó para garantizar equipaje de mano gratuito, mejor información sobre el equipaje y para eliminar cargos extra por errores pequeños como la ortografía del nombre o tarjetas de embarque. Se prestó especial atención a viajeros vulnerables, como personas con discapacidad, mujeres embarazadas, niños y bebés, asegurando prioridad en el embarque y asistencia sin costo adicional. El comité también quiere acelerar los reembolsos exigiendo que las aerolíneas envíen formularios de reclamación prellenados dentro de las 48 horas tras retrasos o cancelaciones.

**Impacto** – Esta decisión protege a millones de pasajeros en la UE al asegurar derechos claros y compensaciones justas. También facilita el viaje para grupos vulnerables que enfrentan más dificultades. Al eliminar algunos cargos extra y mejorar los procesos de reclamación, los pasajeros pueden recibir ayuda más rápido y evitar confusiones. Las reglas también establecen límites claros a los costos para las aerolíneas, equilibrando la justicia con las necesidades comerciales.

**Próximo paso** – La decisión del comité será votada por todo el Parlamento Europeo en enero. Si se aprueba, comenzarán negociaciones con los países miembros para finalizar las nuevas reglas. Este proceso podría llevar a protecciones más fuertes y claras para los pasajeros en toda Europa.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El Parlamento Europeo fortalece los derechos de los pasajeros aéreos para garantizar compensaciones justas, mejores servicios y atención especial a viajeros vulnerables.

articles.title: UN World Court begins landmark hearings on Rohingya genocide case against Myanmar
articles.summary: Public hearings opened on Monday at the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in a landmark case brought by the Gambia against Myanmar, alleging violations of the Genocide Convention over the military’s treatment of the Rohingya minority.
articles.content:
The proceedings, held at the Peace Palace in The Hague, mark the start of the merits phase in the case, after years of preliminary legal arguments.

Over the next three weeks, ICJ judges will hear oral arguments from both sides, examine witnesses and experts, and consider whether Myanmar breached its obligations under the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, to which the country is a party.

Opening the hearings, Judge Iwasawa Yuji, President of the Court, outlined a detailed schedule that includes two rounds of pleadings by Gambia and Myanmar, as well as closed sessions to hear testimony from witnesses called by the applicant State.

Speaking on behalf of Gambia, Attorney General and Minister of Justice Dawda Jallow told the court that his country brought the case “after reviewing credible reports of the most brutal and vicious violations imaginable” committed against the Rohingya, a Muslim minority in Myanmar’s Rakhine province.

“By all measures, this case is not about esoteric issues of international law,” Mr. Jallow said. “It is about real people, real stories, and a real group of human beings.”

© ICJ/Frank van Beek A file photograph of the International Court of Justice.

A case years in the making

Gambia filed its application in November 2019, accusing Myanmar of breaching the Genocide Convention through acts allegedly committed during so-called “clearance operations” carried out by the Myanmar military, or Tatmadaw.

Those operations escalated sharply in 2017, prompting more than 700,000 Rohingya to flee to neighbouring Bangladesh amid widespread killings, sexual violence, village burnings and other abuses. Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the then UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, described the situation as a “textbook example of ethnic cleansing.”

A UN Human Rights Council-mandated fact-finding mission said in 2018 that it had reasonable grounds to conclude that serious crimes under international law, including genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, had been committed.

Nearly one million Rohingya remain living as refugees in camps in Bangladesh, while countless others are displaced or trapped inside Myanmar in dire conditions.

Provisional measures

In January 2020, the Court unanimously ordered provisional measures, directing Myanmar to take all steps within its power to prevent genocidal acts against the Rohingya, preserve evidence, and report regularly to the Court on its compliance.

Myanmar challenged the Court’s jurisdiction, but in July 2022 the judges ruled that they were competent to hear the case.

Eleven States also made written submissions in support of Gambia’s interpretation of the Genocide Convention.

Pierre Peron/OCHA A file photograph of an IDP camp in Rakhine state, Myanmar.

Accountability and broader context

Addressing the judges, Mr. Jallow said Myanmar remained trapped in “a cycle of atrocities and impunity,” noting that no one had been held accountable for crimes against the Rohingya.

He also pointed to the February 2021 military coup, which overthrew the civilian government and plunged Myanmar into renewed nationwide conflict.

“Accountability is imperative,” he said, warning that impunity risks the repetition of atrocity crimes.

Myanmar’s arguments

Myanmar is expected to begin presenting its arguments later this week. The Court’s final judgment, which could take months or longer after the hearings conclude, will be legally binding.

The International Court of Justice is the United Nations’ principal judicial organ. It settles legal disputes between States and gives advisory opinions on questions of international law.

Unlike criminal courts, it does not try individuals but determines State responsibility.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the landmark International Court of Justice hearings addressing alleged genocide against the Rohingya minority in Myanmar, a significant step toward accountability and justice for a large persecuted population. This case has broad humanitarian implications and represents a major effort in international law to prevent and punish genocide, offering hope for justice and protection of human rights.
articles.personality_title: International Court of Justice begins hearings on Rohingya genocide case against Myanmar
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Rohingya are a Muslim minority group in Myanmar’s Rakhine state. Since 2017, many have fled violence and abuses by the Myanmar military, leading to accusations of genocide. The Gambia brought a case to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) accusing Myanmar of breaking international law by committing genocide against the Rohingya.

**What happened** – On Monday, the ICJ in The Hague started public hearings on this case. Over three weeks, judges will listen to arguments from both Myanmar and Gambia, hear witnesses and experts, and decide if Myanmar violated the Genocide Convention, a treaty meant to prevent and punish genocide. The court president outlined a detailed schedule, including closed sessions for sensitive testimonies.

**Impact** – This is one of the most important legal steps taken to hold a country responsible for genocide in recent years. It focuses on real people who suffered serious crimes like killings, sexual violence, and forced displacement. The case highlights the ongoing struggles of nearly one million Rohingya refugees living in difficult conditions. The court’s previous orders have already pushed Myanmar to protect evidence and avoid further harm.

**What’s next step** – Myanmar will present its defense later this week. After all arguments and evidence are heard, the court will take time to make a final decision. This judgment will be legally binding on Myanmar, meaning the country must follow the court’s ruling. The case could influence how the world handles genocide and state responsibility in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The ICJ’s hearings mark a crucial move toward legal accountability for the Rohingya genocide and highlight the international community’s effort to uphold justice through law.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Cour internationale de justice entame les audiences sur le génocide des Rohingyas contre le Myanmar
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les Rohingyas sont une minorité musulmane dans l’État de Rakhine au Myanmar. Depuis 2017, beaucoup fuient la violence et les abus commis par l’armée du Myanmar, ce qui a conduit à des accusations de génocide. La Gambie a saisi la Cour internationale de justice (CIJ) accusant le Myanmar de violer le droit international en commettant un génocide.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, la CIJ à La Haye a commencé les audiences publiques sur cette affaire. Pendant trois semaines, les juges écouteront les arguments du Myanmar et de la Gambie, entendront des témoins et des experts, et décideront si le Myanmar a enfreint la Convention sur le génocide, un traité visant à prévenir et punir ce crime. Le président de la cour a présenté un calendrier détaillé, incluant des sessions à huis clos pour des témoignages sensibles.

**Impact** – C’est une étape juridique majeure pour tenir un pays responsable d’un génocide ces dernières années. L’affaire concerne des personnes réelles ayant subi des crimes graves comme des tueries, des violences sexuelles et des déplacements forcés. Elle met en lumière les difficultés de près d’un million de réfugiés rohingyas vivant dans des conditions difficiles. Les ordonnances précédentes de la cour ont déjà poussé le Myanmar à protéger les preuves et à éviter d’autres dommages.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Myanmar présentera sa défense cette semaine. Après l’audition de tous les arguments et preuves, la cour prendra le temps de rendre une décision finale. Ce jugement sera juridiquement contraignant pour le Myanmar, ce qui signifie que le pays devra respecter la décision. Cette affaire pourrait influencer la manière dont le monde traite le génocide et la responsabilité des États à l’avenir.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les audiences de la CIJ marquent une avancée importante vers la justice pour le génocide des Rohingyas et montrent l’effort international pour faire respecter la loi.
articles.personality_title_es: La Corte Internacional de Justicia inicia audiencias sobre el caso de genocidio Rohingya contra Myanmar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los rohinyás son una minoría musulmana en el estado de Rakhine, Myanmar. Desde 2017, muchos han huido de la violencia y abusos del ejército de Myanmar, lo que ha llevado a acusaciones de genocidio. Gambia presentó un caso ante la Corte Internacional de Justicia (CIJ) acusando a Myanmar de violar la ley internacional al cometer genocidio.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, la CIJ en La Haya comenzó las audiencias públicas sobre este caso. Durante tres semanas, los jueces escucharán los argumentos de Myanmar y Gambia, examinarán testigos y expertos, y decidirán si Myanmar violó la Convención para la Prevención y Sanción del Delito de Genocidio, un tratado para prevenir y castigar el genocidio. El presidente de la corte presentó un calendario detallado, incluyendo sesiones cerradas para testimonios sensibles.

**Impacto** – Este es un paso legal muy importante para responsabilizar a un país por genocidio en años recientes. Se trata de personas reales que sufrieron crímenes graves como asesinatos, violencia sexual y desplazamientos forzados. El caso muestra las dificultades de casi un millón de refugiados rohinyás que viven en condiciones duras. Las órdenes previas del tribunal ya han obligado a Myanmar a proteger pruebas y evitar más daños.

**Próximo paso** – Myanmar presentará su defensa esta semana. Después de escuchar todos los argumentos y pruebas, la corte tomará tiempo para dar un fallo final. Esta decisión será legalmente vinculante para Myanmar, lo que significa que el país debe acatarla. El caso podría influir en cómo el mundo maneja el genocidio y la responsabilidad estatal en el futuro.

**Frase clave** – Las audiencias de la CIJ representan un paso clave hacia la responsabilidad legal por el genocidio Rohingya y muestran el esfuerzo internacional por hacer cumplir la justicia mediante la ley.

articles.title: ‘Beyond GDP’ economists push for clearer metrics on wellbeing, sustainability
articles.summary: Top finance experts are meeting at UN Geneva this week to push for a radical shake up in the way economic growth is gauged, in response to concerns that GDP measurements provide little insight about progress on key sustainability targets that are vital to our survival.
articles.content:
Backed by the UN trade and development agency, UNCTAD and other partners, the “Beyond GDP” initiative acknowledges a warning from Secretary-General António Guterres that global policymaking is over-reliant on Global Domestic Product data.

“ Every day, we witness the consequences of our failure to balance economic, social and environmental dimensions of development,” the Secretary-General has said. “Moving beyond GDP is fundamental to building an economic system that gives value to what counts – human wellbeing – now and in the future, and for everyone.”

His view echoes that of many senior economists, who have said frequently that GDP places too much value on activities that deplete the planet, rather than those that sustain life and contribute to people’s wellbeing.

“This tension has become increasingly salient in the context of climate change, deteriorating ecosystems and biodiversity loss, rising conflict and food insecurity, and historic inequalities,” a statement from the High-Level Expert Group notes.

Gauging wealth and wellbeing

Their discussions later this week at the Palace of Nations in Geneva will be the second in-person meeting of the expert group since it was founded in May last year, after UN Member States signed the 2024 Pact for the Future; its aims include making global governance more inclusive and effective.

“Our approach will emphasize how better well-being and its drivers - such as health, social capital and the quality of the environment - are not only good for societal welfare but also contribute in an integral way to economic prosperity,” the expert group said in an interim report published in November.

Outlining the challenge the group must address, its members warned of “an increasing gap between what politicians and citizens believe is happening, and the latter’s life experiences [which] are not matched by the story told by GDP alone”.

More than a dozen renowned economists will be contributing to this week’s discussions in the Swiss city; they include Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz, Indian economist Kaushik Basu and equity expert Nora Lustig.

Their tasks include developing an initial list of country-owned and universally-applicable indicators of sustainable development to form a dashboard that equips governments with the information they need to meet the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

The expert group will also provide guidance on how to maximize uptake of the dashboard and how to prioritize data collection in order to operationalize the dashboard and SDG indicators.

In addition to support from UNCTAD, the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA), the UN Development Programme (UNDP) and the Executive Office of the Secretary-General will continue to partner the initiative.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant initiative backed by the UN and top economists to reform how economic progress is measured, shifting focus from GDP to wellbeing and sustainability. This has broad societal implications by promoting policies that better address human wellbeing, environmental sustainability, and social equity, aligning with global Sustainable Development Goals. The story is substantive, focused, and highlights a meaningful effort to improve global governance and quality of life.
articles.personality_title: UN experts seek new ways to measure wellbeing beyond GDP
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many countries use Gross Domestic Product (GDP) to measure how well their economies are doing. But GDP mainly counts money made and spent, without showing if people are healthier, happier, or if the environment is safe and clean.

**What happened** – This week, top economists and UN officials met in Geneva to discuss better ways to measure progress. They want to include factors like health, nature, and social fairness, not just money. This meeting is part of the “Beyond GDP” project, supported by the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and others.

**Impact** – This effort is important because GDP alone doesn’t tell the full story about how well people live or if the planet is safe. For example, a country might grow its economy but harm its forests or make people sick. The new approach aims to help governments make smarter choices that protect both people and nature.

**What’s next step** – The experts will create a list of new measurements that countries can use to track progress on the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). They will also work on ways to help governments collect and use this information better.

**One-sentence takeaway** – UN experts are working to change how we measure progress, focusing on wellbeing and the environment instead of just economic numbers.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les experts de l’ONU veulent de nouveaux indicateurs de bien-être au-delà du PIB
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – De nombreux pays utilisent le Produit Intérieur Brut (PIB) pour mesurer la santé de leur économie. Mais le PIB compte surtout l’argent gagné et dépensé, sans montrer si les gens sont en meilleure santé, plus heureux ou si l’environnement est sûr et propre.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Cette semaine, des économistes et responsables de l’ONU se sont réunis à Genève pour discuter de meilleures façons de mesurer le progrès. Ils veulent inclure des facteurs comme la santé, la nature et la justice sociale, pas seulement l’argent. Cette réunion fait partie du projet « Au-delà du PIB », soutenu par la Conférence des Nations Unies sur le commerce et le développement (CNUCED) et d’autres.

**Impact** – Cette démarche est importante car le PIB seul ne raconte pas toute l’histoire du bien-être des gens ou de la protection de la planète. Par exemple, un pays peut faire croître son économie tout en détruisant ses forêts ou en rendant les gens malades. La nouvelle approche vise à aider les gouvernements à faire des choix plus intelligents qui protègent à la fois les personnes et la nature.

**Prochaine étape** – Les experts vont créer une liste de nouveaux indicateurs que les pays pourront utiliser pour suivre les progrès des 17 Objectifs de développement durable (ODD). Ils travailleront aussi à aider les gouvernements à mieux collecter et utiliser ces données.

**Une phrase clé** – Les experts de l’ONU veulent changer la façon de mesurer le progrès, en se concentrant sur le bien-être et l’environnement plutôt que sur les chiffres économiques seuls.
articles.personality_title_es: Expertos de la ONU buscan nuevas formas de medir el bienestar más allá del PIB
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchos países usan el Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) para medir cómo está su economía. Pero el PIB solo cuenta el dinero que se gana y gasta, sin mostrar si las personas están más saludables, felices o si el medio ambiente está limpio y seguro.

**Qué pasó** – Esta semana, economistas y funcionarios de la ONU se reunieron en Ginebra para hablar sobre mejores maneras de medir el progreso. Quieren incluir factores como la salud, la naturaleza y la justicia social, no solo el dinero. Esta reunión es parte del proyecto “Más allá del PIB”, apoyado por la Conferencia de las Naciones Unidas sobre Comercio y Desarrollo (UNCTAD) y otros.

**Impacto** – Este esfuerzo es importante porque el PIB no cuenta toda la historia sobre cómo viven las personas o si el planeta está protegido. Por ejemplo, un país puede crecer económicamente pero dañar sus bosques o enfermar a su gente. El nuevo enfoque busca ayudar a los gobiernos a tomar decisiones más inteligentes que protejan tanto a las personas como a la naturaleza.

**Próximo paso** – Los expertos crearán una lista de nuevas mediciones que los países puedan usar para seguir el progreso de los 17 Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible (ODS). También trabajarán en cómo ayudar a los gobiernos a recolectar y usar mejor esta información.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Expertos de la ONU trabajan para cambiar cómo medimos el progreso, enfocándose en el bienestar y el medio ambiente, no solo en números económicos.

articles.title: A voice for the unheard in Myanmar: From the Rakhine coast to the frontlines of truth
articles.summary: "We decided to present the resilience of female journalists across Myanmar who are working in war-torn areas, rather than focusing solely on our own story."
articles.content:
Exile Hub is one of Global Voices’ partners in Southeast Asia, emerging in response to the 2021 coup in Myanmar, focusing on empowering journalists and human rights defenders. This edited article is republished under a content partnership agreement.

Nay Nay’s journey began not in a bustling newsroom, but on the serene Rakhine coast of Myanmar. Yet fate had a different path in store, one that led her into the heart of truth-telling during Myanmar’s darkest moments.

The military coup shattered Myanmar’s fragile peace in 2021. Journalists quickly became targets, and the danger of arrest grew impossible to ignore. As the risk to her partner, also a woman journalist, intensified, Nay Nay made the agonizing decision to flee their homeland together. They sought refuge along the Thai–Myanmar border, a place of safety from persecution. In exile, Nay Nay continues her work as a news presenter at Lay Waddyi FM and, above all, a storyteller.

When Nay Nay first applied for the Feminist Storytelling Grant under Exile Hub, they planned to tell a deeply personal story of a lesbian couple navigating journalism amid conflict and displacement. It was a story of love, survival, and resilience. But as conversations unfolded, a broader and more urgent truth emerged.

“As we gradually discussed the idea, we decided to present the resilience of female journalists across Myanmar who are working in war-torn areas, rather than focusing solely on our own story.”

This realization led to “Female Journalists in the War Zone,” a podcast amplifying the untold stories of women reporters working on the ground in Rakhine, Karenni, Kachin, and Sagaing. Through their voices, the podcast brings their challenges, triumphs, and resilience directly to the public.

Nyein Nyein’s definition of a feminist is simple yet meaningful,

“Feminists are people who stand in solidarity with and support the capabilities of women.”

When she fled Myanmar, she humbly admits she wasn't a “fully qualified media professional.” Yet, that hasn't deterred her. With the steadfast support of her partner, she continues to produce programs tirelessly, using her voice to uplift and encourage other women in the region while constantly learning, growing, and refining her craft.

Her commitment to human rights and women's issues has come at a cost. She has endured immense pressure, threats, and attacks from nationalist extremists, particularly online, where hateful comments flood the pages beneath her reports.

In times of extreme difficulty, when financial stability wavers, Nay Nay takes on part-time jobs, not just to survive, but to sustain her reporting. Her motivation is clear:

“This is because I want to stand up for women in the dark, those who lack access to information. It is also my main reason why I want to be a news presenter.”

For the women who listen to her, Nay Nay carries a deep sense of responsibility. She faces her own challenges with quiet resolve, relying on trusted senior sisters, mentors, and colleagues to help carry the weight of her work.

“I simply want to be a useful person somewhere in the media industry and a person who does not poison the public.”

Nay Nay is more than a news presenter. She is a guardian of truth, a sister in solidarity, and a resilient voice in the face of darkness. Her story stands as a testament to the unyielding spirit of those who continue to pursue justice even at great personal cost.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the resilience and courageous work of female journalists in Myanmar amid conflict and oppression, showcasing their efforts to amplify truth and support women's rights under dangerous conditions. This has broad significance for human rights, freedom of expression, and gender equality in a war-torn society, with substantial context and impact described.
articles.personality_title: Female journalists in Myanmar share stories from the frontline of conflict
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2021, Myanmar experienced a military coup that disrupted peace and made it dangerous for journalists to work freely. Many faced arrest or threats, forcing some to flee the country.

**What happened** – Nay Nay, a female journalist from Myanmar’s Rakhine coast, fled to the Thai–Myanmar border with her partner to escape danger. In exile, she continues reporting and launched a podcast called “Female Journalists in the War Zone.” This podcast highlights the experiences of women reporters working in Myanmar’s conflict areas like Rakhine, Karenni, Kachin, and Sagaing.

**Impact** – The podcast brings attention to the courage and challenges of female journalists who risk their safety to share important news. Nay Nay’s work supports women’s voices in a country where information is often controlled or blocked. Despite facing online threats and financial struggles, she remains dedicated to helping women who lack access to news.

**What's next step** – Nay Nay and her team will keep producing stories that show the reality of life in war zones, helping the world understand what is happening. Their work may inspire more support for press freedom and women’s rights in Myanmar.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Despite great risks, female journalists like Nay Nay continue to tell vital stories from Myanmar’s conflict zones, giving a voice to those often unheard.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des femmes journalistes au Myanmar racontent la guerre depuis la ligne de front
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2021, un coup d’État militaire a bouleversé la paix au Myanmar, rendant le travail des journalistes dangereux. Beaucoup ont été menacés ou arrêtés, et certains ont dû fuir le pays.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Nay Nay, journaliste originaire de la côte de Rakhine, a fui vers la frontière thaïlandaise avec son partenaire pour échapper au danger. En exil, elle continue à informer et a lancé un podcast intitulé « Femmes journalistes en zone de guerre », qui raconte les expériences de femmes reporters dans les régions en conflit du Myanmar.

**Impact** – Ce podcast met en lumière le courage et les difficultés des femmes journalistes qui risquent leur sécurité pour informer. Le travail de Nay Nay soutient la voix des femmes dans un pays où l’accès à l’information est souvent limité. Malgré les menaces en ligne et les difficultés financières, elle reste engagée à aider celles qui n’ont pas accès à l’information.

**Prochaine étape** – Nay Nay et son équipe continueront à produire des reportages qui montrent la réalité des zones de conflit, aidant le monde à mieux comprendre la situation. Leur travail pourrait encourager plus de soutien à la liberté de la presse et aux droits des femmes au Myanmar.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Malgré de grands risques, des femmes journalistes comme Nay Nay racontent des histoires essentielles des zones de conflit au Myanmar, donnant une voix à ceux qu’on n’entend pas souvent.
articles.personality_title_es: Mujeres periodistas en Myanmar cuentan historias desde la línea de frente del conflicto
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2021, un golpe militar interrumpió la paz en Myanmar, haciendo que el trabajo de los periodistas fuera peligroso. Muchos enfrentaron amenazas o arrestos y algunos tuvieron que huir del país.

**Qué pasó** – Nay Nay, periodista de la costa de Rakhine, huyó a la frontera entre Tailandia y Myanmar con su pareja para escapar del peligro. En el exilio, sigue informando y lanzó un podcast llamado “Mujeres periodistas en zona de guerra” que cuenta las experiencias de mujeres reporteras en áreas de conflicto en Myanmar.

**Impacto** – El podcast muestra el valor y los retos de las mujeres periodistas que arriesgan su seguridad para compartir noticias importantes. El trabajo de Nay Nay apoya las voces femeninas en un país donde la información a menudo está controlada o bloqueada. A pesar de amenazas en línea y dificultades económicas, ella sigue comprometida a ayudar a quienes no tienen acceso a noticias.

**Próximo paso** – Nay Nay y su equipo continuarán produciendo historias que muestran la realidad de las zonas de guerra, ayudando al mundo a entender mejor lo que sucede. Su trabajo podría inspirar más apoyo a la libertad de prensa y los derechos de las mujeres en Myanmar.

**Resumen en una frase** – A pesar de grandes riesgos, mujeres periodistas como Nay Nay continúan contando historias vitales desde las zonas de conflicto en Myanmar, dando voz a quienes a menudo no son escuchados.
